column1: Fairwood is an unincorporated community and census-designated place (CDP) in King County
column2: Washington
column3: United States. As of the 2010 census the population was 19
16 miles (26 km) southeast of downtown Seattle. The Fairwood CDP is bordered to the north and west by the city of Renton and to the east by the Maple Heights-Lake Desire CDP
column4: which shares a ZIP Code (Renton's 98058) with Fairwood. Population and demographic statistics in this article are only for the Fairwood CDP

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the CDP has a total area of 4.9 square miles (12.6 km2).The Fairwood area occupies a plateau which extends from the bluffs of the Cedar River valley on the north down toward State Route 167 and the Kent Valley on the west.

column1: Fairwood's climate features cool/mild wet winters and dry summers. The warmest month of the year is July
column2: and the coldest is December.
winter
column3: and spring are frequently characterized by rain in the Seattle area
column4: while the summers are fairly dry and warm by comparison. Fairwood's location closer to downslope winds from the Cascade Range means it can get fairly hot in the summers. An exception to the damp weather occurs in El Niño years when the Seattle area stays fairly dry.

column1: Fairwood typically receives some snowfall on an annual basis
column2: but heavy snow is rare.

column1: The following parks and recreation areas are within the Fairwood CDP:
Fairwood Golf & Country Club – A large 18 hole golf course located in the Fairwood Greens neighborhood. It features 6
column2: 316 yards of golf from the longest tees for a par of 71. The country club includes a heated 8-lane junior Olympic sized pool

column1: Petrovitsky Park – Located just north of Petrovitsky Rd
column2: an 88-acre park with 4 baseball fields and soccer fields
column4: and picnic areas.Other areas outside the CDP but still considered within the Fairwood area are:

column1: Spring Lake / Lake Desire Park – Located in eastern Fairwood between Lake Desire and Spring Lake. It features an 11-mile backcountry trail for hiking
column2: horseback riding and mountain biking.

column1: Soos Creek Trail and Park – In western Fairwood
column2: home to a large riparian habitat great for birdwatching of ducks
column4: and raptors. The 12 mile long Soos Creek trail was extended up to Fairwood in the late 2000s.

column1: McGarvey Park – Features a 1.2 mile hiking trail up Cedar Mountain (Echo Mountain) through evergreen forest
column2: passing over Peterson Creek. It has views of Mount Rainier on the summit of Cedar Mountain.

column1: Cedar River Trail – North of the Fairwood plateau the trail hugs the winding Cedar River from Renton to Maple Valley.
The Fairwood CDP is served by two school districts
column2: Renton and Kent. The Tahoma School District covers parts of the Fairwood ZIP code area that are within the neighboring Maple Heights-Lake Desire CDP. Schools serving the Fairwood area are:

column1: There are three major arterials that run through Fairwood. Petrovitsky Road runs east/west through Fairwood's commercial core and many of its neighborhoods. It stretches from downtown Renton
column2: near the Boeing Renton Factory
column3: and Boeing Commercial Aviation; where many Fairwood residents work
column7: and farms of eastern Fairwood. 140th Avenue runs north/south adjacent to the Fairwood shopping centers and Soos Creek. It stretches from Maple Valley highway on the north and leads 9 miles to Green River Community College by way of Kent's east hill. State Route 169 (Maple Valley highway) on the northern end of Fairwood provides short access to Interstate 405.

column1: Fairwood Fire Protection and Emergency Medical Services are served by Fire Districts 40 and 37. The Fire District 40 station is located on Petrovitsky Road in the center of Fairwood. Fairwood Fire Protection and Emergency Medical Services are served by Fire Districts 40 and 37. The Fire District 40 station is located on Petrovitsky Road in the center of Fairwood. column2: Cascade-Fairwood leans towards candidates of the Democratic Party. Democrat John Kerry received about 56 percent of the vote in 2004 to Republican George W. Bush's 43 percent. Despite this
column3: there are a number of pockets where the Republican Party often wins marginal majorities.

column2: the Fairwood Task Force filed a Notice of Intent to Incorporation with King County
column3: to establish a new City of Fairwood. This attempt to incorporate was narrowly defeated in the election held on September 19
column5: 48.22% of the votes were for incorporation; a swing of only 136 votes in the election would have changed the result.

column1: The process to form a City of Fairwood was restarted by the Fairwood Municipal Initiative when it filed another Notice of Proposed Incorporation with King County
column2: Washington on April 16
column4: the incorporation effort is now under the jurisdiction of the King County Boundary Review Board (BRB) and a consulting firm hired by the BRB is conducting an economic feasibility study for the proposed city of Fairwood.

column2: 2009 Proposition 1 to incorporate a city of Fairwood failed again

column1: Efforts are also ongoing to annex the Fairwood area into the city of Renton. Additionally
column2: the Red Mill area of the Fairwood PAA is presently undertaking a separate petition-method annexation.On November 2
column4: 57.6% of voters voted against a proposition to annex Fairwood to Renton.
